thread.title: Husband charged in wife's death: A look at Kelley and Thomas Clayton
thread.title_full: Husband charged in wife's death: A look at Kelley and Thomas Clayton

author: Bob Jamieson, rjamieson@stargazette.com
title: Husband charged in wife's death: A look at Kelley and Thomas Clayton
text:
The Caton woman found dead early Tuesday in her Ginnan Road home grew up in West Elmira and was married to a former Elmira Jackals hockey player who has now been charged with murder in her death. Kelley Stage Clayton and her husband, Thomas Clayton, a West Side Binghamton native who played hockey for just more than four seasons with the Jackals, had two young children.
Clayton, 37, was arraigned on a charge of second-degree murder Tuesday afternoon in Caton Town Court.
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE
Former minor league hockey player charged with killing wife
The victim grew up as Kelley Stage, the youngest of three children of Elizabeth Stage and the late Howard E. Stage, a longtime fire chief for the West Elmira Volunteer Fire Department.
Kelley Stage Clayton, 35, was a 1998 graduate of Elmira Free Academy, where she was an honor roll student and participated on the cheerleading squad and softball team, according to Star-Gazette archives.
She later attended SUNY Oneonta and after college lived in Nevada for a period of time before returning to the area, according to the archives.
Former Niagara Univ. Hockey Player Charged With Murder
Clayton and his wife met while he was playing for the Jackals, according to the 2014 Star-Gazette story that profiled six former Jackals players who stayed in the area after retiring from minor-league hockey.
At the time of the story, written 21 months ago, their children were 5 and 2.
Clayton owns and operates a business franchise in Elmira, Paul Davis Emergency Services of the Southern Tier, a fire and water damage restoration firm.
He joined the Jackals as a forward late in their second season right out of Niagara University, where he played hockey four seasons, from 1998 to 2002.
"I wanted to pursue a career in hockey. I wanted to play somewhere, and I thought Elmira would be a great fit. I had family in Binghamton, and they could see me play," Clayton said in the Jan. 26, 2014, article.
He played 14 games in 2001-02, his first season with the Jackals, then a member of the United Hockey League, according to hockeydb.com . He played the next four seasons for the Jackals before being traded 14 games into the 2005-06 season. He went to the Quad City Mallards, where he finished the season and retired, according to newspaper archives.
Law enforcement officials were called to 2181 Ginnan Road in Caton for a suspicious death report. Steuben County Sheriff Office, Caton Police and New York State Police were on scene searching the nearby property and home. You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide In April 2003, Clayton and another former Jackals player, Brad Wingfield, were charged in a well-publicized, late-night fight with four Elmira police cadets that spilled outside a downtown Elmira bar and into Water Street, according to newspaper archives. Clayton was charged with public lewdness and harassment for dancing nearly naked on the bar, behavior that sparked a confrontation with the cadets, the story said. Wingfield, the enforcer on the Jackals team, was charged with felony assault, the archives said. Months later, both pleaded guilty to reduced charges of disorderly conduct.
During his second unsuccessful tryout with the Binghamton Senators' American Hockey League team, Clayton scored a few goals in practice in September 2004 against top NHL goalie Dominik Hasek, according to a Sept. 29, 2004, story in the Press & Sun-Bulletin, of Binghamton.
"I got hurt, I got married. It was a different phase of my life," Clayton said in the 2014 story. "The minors is not all glory like the NHL. You're riding on buses many hours and many days. At that point in my life, I had to make a decision. Did I want to bounce around the minors, or start a family and do other things?"
The story said he chose family over hockey, and they relocated to Charlotte, North Carolina, for five years, where Clayton owned some properties.
In Charlotte, he started a business where he would drive people home who had too much to drink, then sold that business and returned to the Southern Tier to operate his own Paul Davis franchise, according to the story. Upon his return, he also teamed up with another retired Jackals player, James Sheehan, to buy and manage multi-unit properties, according to the Star-Gazette story.
Follow Bob Jamieson on Twitter @SGBob
